insights.content: Shopify optimizes for the 100-year view. Requires prioritizing the long-tail of entrepreneurs (who will be the giants of tomorrow) over quick enterprise revenue wins today (companies that might die in 50 years).
insights.quotation: The decisions we're going to make are really oriented towards the long-term success of merchants, of Shopify... we are here to build a 100 year company.

insights.title: Unconventional product lessons from Binance, N26, Google, more | Mayur Kamat (CPO at N26)

insights.content: Launch features that unblock users immediately, even if they aren't perfect. Speed is a feature.
insights.quotation: In crypto, usually the opportunity cost of not launching is higher than the cost of launching something that's broken.

insights.content: Don't just copy competitors. Understand the underlying user need that the competitor is solving.
insights.quotation: You can Copy-Paste the feature, but you can't Copy-Paste the insight.

insights.content: In high-growth markets, acquiring users is often about removing friction rather than adding value.
insights.quotation: Sometimes the best growth hack is just making sure the sign-up button works.

insights.title: Lessons from Atlassian | Megan Cook (Head of Product, Jira)

insights.content: Fixing the 'Jira tax': Focus on performance and usability to win back user trust.
insights.quotation: We realized we had to pay down the debt of complexity we had built up over a decade.

insights.content: Democratize customer interviews. Engineers and designers should be talking to users, not just PMs.
insights.quotation: It changes the conversation when an engineer sees a user struggle with their code.

insights.content: The 'triad' (PM, Engineering, Design) is the fundamental unit of decision making at Atlassian.
insights.quotation: No decision gets made without the triad being aligned.

insights.title: She turned 100+ rejections into a $42B company | Melanie Perkins

insights.content: Start with a niche (yearbooks) to prove the model before expanding to the entire market.
insights.quotation: We didn't start with 'design for everyone'. We started with 'yearbooks for schools'.

insights.content: Resilience is key. 100 rejections taught me to refine the pitch, not abandon the vision.
insights.quotation: Every 'no' was just feedback on how to get to the 'yes'.

insights.content: Empower users by making complex tools accessible. democratize design.
insights.quotation: Our goal was to make design simple for everyone, not just designers.

insights.title: Everything you’ve ever wanted to know about SAFe and the product owner role

insights.content: The 'Product Owner' is a role in Scrum, not a job title. The job is Product Management.
insights.quotation: If you only focus on the 'Owner' part, you become a backlog administrator.

insights.content: SAFe often fails because it's implemented as a rigorous process rather than a mindset shift.
insights.quotation: You can't process your way to product innovation.

insights.content: Strategy is not a fixed plan; it's a framework for decision making.
insights.quotation: Good strategy enables teams to say 'no' to good ideas.

insights.title: The ultimate guide to product operations | Melissa Perri and Denise Tilles

insights.content: Product Ops is about enabling the product team to function effectively, not controlling them.
insights.quotation: Product Ops should be the oil in the machine, not the driver.

insights.content: The three pillars of Product Ops: Data/Insights, Customer/Market Research, and Process/Governance.
insights.quotation: If you don't have good data, you can't make good decisions.

insights.content: Don't start a Product Ops team until you have a clear scaling problem to solve.
insights.quotation: Don't hire Product Ops just because it's trendy. Hire it to fix pain.

insights.title: Building high-performing teams | Melissa Tan (Webflow, Dropbox, Canva)

insights.content: Growth models change at scale. What got you to $10M won't get you to $100M.
insights.quotation: You have to be willing to kill the process that made you successful yesterday.

insights.content: Hire for 'slope' (trajectory) over 'y-intercept' (current skill level) in high-growth environments.
insights.quotation: I look for people who are learning faster than the company is growing.

insights.content: Alignment is the biggest bottleneck to speed in scaling organizations.
insights.quotation: Speed comes from clarity, not just working harder.

insights.title: An inside look at Deel’s unprecedented growth | Meltem Kuran Berkowitz (Head

insights.content: Speed is a cultural value that starts at the top. Deel literally measures response times metrics.
insights.quotation: People think we are crazy, but speed is our strategy.

insights.content: Don't build for every edge case. Solve the 80% that matters most and fix the rest later.
insights.quotation: Perfect is the enemy of the done, especially in fintech.

insights.content: Hyper-growth requires constant reorganization. Your role today will not be your role in 6 months.
insights.quotation: If you want comfort, don't join a rocket ship.

insights.title: How to work through fear, give hard feedback, and doing layoffs with grace

insights.content: Hard feedback is kinder than silence. 'Ruinous Empathy' kills teams.
insights.quotation: Being nice is not the same as being kind. Kindness is telling the truth.

insights.content: Managing through fear: Acknowledge the fear, but focus on the work.
insights.quotation: Courage isn't the absence of fear; it's acting despite it.

insights.content: Layoffs are a failure of management, but must be executed with dignity for those leaving.
insights.quotation: How you treat people on their way out defines your culture.

insights.title: The rise of Cursor: The $300M ARR AI tool that engineers can’t stop using

insights.content: To displace an incumbent (VS Code), you have to be 10x better on their home turf.
insights.quotation: We couldn't just be an AI plugin. We had to be a better editor.

insights.content: AI coding tools aren't just autocomplete; they are reasoning engines for your codebase.
insights.quotation: The model knows your code better than you do.

insights.content: The future of engineering is 'spec-driven development' where humans define intent and AI handles implementation.
insights.quotation: We are moving from writing code to writing specs.

insights.title: Mina Radhakrishnan on Lead-User Innovation at Uber

insights.content: Innovation often comes from 'lead users' who are already hacking your product to solve advanced problems. Observe the workarounds to find the next major feature.
insights.quotation: Watch what your power users are doing that you never intended. If they're using a screwdriver as a hammer, maybe you should build a better hammer.

insights.title: Nelson Gil Mendez on Product Operations at Uber

insights.content: Product Ops exists to scale the product team by owning data accessibility, tool standardisation, and the 'operating system' of how product gets built.
insights.quotation: Product Ops shouldn't do the PM's job. It should remove the friction that prevents the PM from doing their job.

insights.title: Noah Weiss on Product Management at Slack

insights.content: Polish is the difference between a tool and a product. Small details (loading states, copy, transitions) build trust and emotional connection with the user.
insights.quotation: If the product feels like magic, it's usually because someone spent 100 hours on a detail that only takes 1 second to experience.

insights.title: Petra Wille on Product Coaching and Growth

insights.content: Manage people, not products. Product leaders should spend 50% of their time coaching individual PMs to improve their specific competencies rather than micro-managing results.
insights.quotation: If you're spending all your time in meetings deciding what features to build, you're not leading people. You're just a high-paid project manager.

insights.title: Ravi Mehta on Product Competence and the 12-Competency Model

insights.content: Evaluate PMs across four key areas: Strategy, Execution, User Insight, and Influence. Each area has 3 sub-skills for a total of 12 distinct competencies.
insights.quotation: Every great PM has a jagged profile. No one is a 10/10 on all 12. The goal is to build a team with complementary jagged edges.

insights.title: Shishir Mehrotra on Rituals and the Coda Way

insights.content: An 'eigenquestion' is the single question that, once answered, makes the answers to all other related questions fall into place.
insights.quotation: Stop debating the roadmap. Find the eigenquestion. Once you solve that, the roadmap becomes obvious.

insights.title: Sridhar Ramaswamy on Vision and Neeva

insights.content: True product leadership requires the ability to look 10 years ahead and build the foundation today. Don't just follow trends; anticipate structural shifts in human behavior.
insights.quotation: If you are playing for the next quarter, you've already lost the next decade. Success comes from the patience to be right about the future.

insights.title: Todd Olson on Pendo's Product-Led Growth

insights.content: A model for PLG: Design for the 'Aha!' moment first, then build features that drive retention, which in turn fuels word-of-mouth acquisition.
insights.quotation: In a product-led world, the product is your best salesperson. If the user doesn't get value in the first 5 minutes, you've lost them.

insights.title: Countdown of the top 10 episodes of the year

insights.content: First step of positioning: Understand Competitive Alternatives. What does the customer do if they don't buy you? (Status quo or other shortlist items).
insights.quotation: The first step in a good positioning exercise is to really understand what do we have to position against? (April Dunford)

insights.content: This episode compiles top insights. Key themes include positioning (Dunford), retention (Widjaja), and product sense (Zhuo).
insights.quotation: A compilation of the best insights from the year.

insights.title: Failure

insights.content: You can often learn more from failure than from success. This episode compiles failure stories from top leaders.
insights.quotation: Normally I spend a lot of time researching how the best companies... operate, but you can learn a lot and often a lot more from failure.

insights.content: Katie Dill shares a story of her design team at Airbnb rebelling against her early tenure, a key learning moment.
insights.quotation: The entire design team at Airbnb basically rebelled against her soon after she joined.

insights.title: Favorite interview questions from top product leaders

insights.content: Eeke De Miliano asks 'To what do you attribute your success?' requiring candidates to look beyond 'luck' and show self-awareness.
insights.quotation: To what do you attribute your success? And you can't say 'luck'.
